titles.name: Developer, Architect, Tech Lead
roles: My first goal was to lead my team to take the ownership of License Optimizer, a legacy product for establishing specific vendor software license position for our customers that is a SaaS offering written in .Net and deployed as monolith. While learning about the domain, we identified the architecture as well as the technical debts we had tackled immediately.

Most importantly, we added database sharding and replication, removed manual tests in favour of automated test suite, created the deployment pipeline up to production including database migrations. All that while adding value for the customers by making changes and fixing bugs.

As a result, License Optimizer is now scalable and ready to accept customers from different regions. Product Team can integrate changes quicker and without significant risk of introducing bugs. Quarterly, manual release with 1 hour downtime became weekly, automated deployment with 5 minutes of unavailability.

Moving forward with License Optimizer adoption, we got a chance to integrate it with Ivanti Cloud. First, we tackled tenant management automation. Then we identified and started extracting some Bounded Contexts from legacy monolith to Ivanti Cloud.

Following the scalability drivers, on deployment level we based our microservices on Service Fabric and communicated them asynchronously with events. Inside the components we opted for Ports and Adapters which decoupled the domain logic from the infrastructure code. We also put considerable effort on Integration Tests harness.
As a result, different License Optimizer capabilities are ready to continue their migration to Ivanti Cloud to make the product more scalable and flexible in regards to offering.

I am very happy that we attempted to grow the product following the ways described in the book Inspired by Marty Cagan, that is by using different Product Discovery techniques involving our customers.

projects.name: Event module for Apsis Pro
projects.summary: An interesting project we worked on for Apsis was about re-architecturing and enriching the existing Event module. The functionality allows for managing sessions, sending invites and reminders via email and SMS, tracking registrations (with seat booking) and attendance and finally gathering feedback. This was one of the first modules of Apsis Pro designed using Domain-Driven Design. We put it together as a SPA with AngularJS and ASP.Net Web API supported by some background processing apps. Notably, a set of public APIs was included that supported registering and managing attendees.

projects.name: Updates to Apsis Pro Integrations
projects.summary: Since Apsis is constantly growing it turned out our existing public API, high volume subscription importers and push integration needed a boost in performance. Interestingly, importers and push are expected to work with data from one to a couple million subscribers. We've done load testing and improving API and importer throughput. We also have rewritten the push integration as a horizontally scalable app based on NServiceBus backed by MSMQ queues.

projects.name: Driver Candidate Profile
projects.summary: This SOAP web service system is used for processing driver candidate data from inception, when a person registers for a driving school, through training and exams to the point when such candidate profile actually becomes input data for a driver's licence doc. We were tasked with designing the XSD schema that supported growing driver candidate history and implementing web services that allow 3rd party to integrate so that the document flow that was once done on paper via post office is now automated over the wire. We gained experience in Windows Communication Foundation and Client Certificates.

projects.name: Vehicle and Driver System
projects.summary: For our public administration client in Poland we've been adding changes and fixing defects in the system used on clerk desktops to process vehicle registration and driver's license docs. It's a distributed Windows Forms (.Net) rich client deployed on a couple hundred departments connecting to one of the few regional SQL Server database instances. Notably, we used Composite UI Application Block together with the Unit of Work pattern. We also automated the deployment to those desktops with Windows batch scripts and the regional partitioning allowed for Canary Releases.
